snippet.textDisplay: I don't know man, i really enjoyed this game. It was short, but the feeling of javelin heaviness and gunfight was really good. I think this game could more than a 6 hour story. Hope Bioware will figure out how to resolve this problem and deliver the rest of the story with more content than this open world playground is right now. Wish them good luck!

snippet.textDisplay: I was there for the closed beta, the open beta, launch with its 8-10 hr server BS, the freezes in the long loading screens, the re-spawn glitches, the boss de-spawn bugs, all the time wasted grinding for better gear....3 weeks after launch, I jumped ship. I’ve recently tried it out again. Bugs are fixed, everything is how it should’ve been at launch or sometime after launch. There’s no content, no thrill in it, especially for us “Legion of the Dawn” owners.
snippet.textOriginal: I was there for the closed beta, the open beta, launch with its 8-10 hr server BS, the freezes in the long loading screens, the re-spawn glitches, the boss de-spawn bugs, all the time wasted grinding for better gear....3 weeks after launch, I jumped ship. I’ve recently tried it out again. Bugs are fixed, everything is how it should’ve been at launch or sometime after launch. There’s no content, no thrill in it, especially for us “Legion of the Dawn” owners.

snippet.textDisplay: i noticed a change in loading screens and loot drop as well as the world events in free roam but i still feel like the game is incomplete. Not only have they yet to add any durable content after cataclysm. But the ending seemed so simple and lack luster that it was really just kinda meh. I understand it goes based off difficulty but i always felt like important end game or boss fights are supposed to surpass difficulty just a bit. Like easy would be medium, medium would be hard, hard would be expert as far as the boss fights etc. But like even the "raids" need a rework because with a decent group they can be done in just a few minutes it doesn't even feel like anything was accomplished. I feel like the existing content is more focused towards new players that i still see coming in where as there is still nothing existing as of yet for older players to keep us satisfied and that definitely needs to be changed and by changed i mean actually added.

Like easy would be medium, medium would be hard, hard would be expert as far as the boss fights etc. But like even the "raids" need a rework because with a decent group they can be done in just a few minutes it doesn't even feel like anything was accomplished. snippet.textDisplay:
Dudes are we still whining about Anthem? Are we actually complaining that a company is trying to improve their product? Are we complaining that they are trying to recoup on an investment? You want people to move on, but who is going to let you move on to anything else important after such a colossal release failure with out improving it, gaining an overall return profit before moving on? If i was a developer, i wouldnt want to move on without being given an opportunity to redeem my name under this Anthem title. Why do you care how much they apologize or not, so long as they put out a great product.

Have any of you played the game currently to criticize the player base and current content, or are you going based totally off the release content and experience.

If you are upset because the game was a great disappointment, i understand that, but why hate on the game being focused on by those that have a love and financial interest in it. If you dont care about Anthem, simply ignore it.

Sounds like the guy on the far right wants and already has a mind set to not even play the game 1st; he wants to stream right away so he can rip on anything he doesn't like about the game live across the internet. Where as Joe at least wants to try 2.0 out 1st. This other guy just has so much hate for Anthem, its very existence is opening old wounds or something. Did he catch Anthem in bed with his wife, and she loved it more than him or something? Damn! 😋

I did go back to Anthem and notice improvements on the game, but didnt stay not because i hated the game, but because i had moved on actually. Anthem ain't the 1st let down when it comes to any purchased media, it already aint the last. But that one guy on your panel needs some closure or something.

Both Joes 👍
snippet.textOriginal:
Dudes are we still whining about Anthem? Are we actually complaining that a company is trying to improve their product? Are we complaining that they are trying to recoup on an investment? You want people to move on, but who is going to let you move on to anything else important after such a colossal release failure with out improving it, gaining an overall return profit before moving on? If i was a developer, i wouldnt want to move on without being given an opportunity to redeem my name under this Anthem title. Why do you care how much they apologize or not, so long as they put out a great product.

Have any of you played the game currently to criticize the player base and current content, or are you going based totally off the release content and experience.

If you are upset because the game was a great disappointment, i understand that, but why hate on the game being focused on by those that have a love and financial interest in it. If you dont care about Anthem, simply ignore it.

Sounds like the guy on the far right wants and already has a mind set to not even play the game 1st; he wants to stream right away so he can rip on anything he doesn't like about the game live across the internet. Where as Joe at least wants to try 2.0 out 1st. This other guy just has so much hate for Anthem, its very existence is opening old wounds or something.  Did he catch Anthem in bed with his wife, and she loved it more than him or something? Damn! 😋

I did go back to Anthem and notice improvements on the game, but didnt stay not because i hated the game, but because i had moved on actually. Anthem ain't the 1st let down when it comes to any purchased media, it already aint the last. But that one guy on your panel needs some closure or something. 

Both Joes 👍

snippet.textDisplay: If they want to save a game and get some ROI, why not complete Mass Effect Andromeda? That game is better than Anthem in every way and it could actually be good with some tweaks to make the quests shorter and less repetitive, the already promised Quarian Ark DLC and a flying vehicle to make navigating the maps less tedious. Even just making all fast travel locations unlocked from the start so that you don't have to spend hours Death Stranding across the maps would make the game much better.
snippet.textOriginal: If they want to save a game and get some ROI, why not complete Mass Effect Andromeda? That game is better than Anthem in every way and it could actually be good with some tweaks to make the quests shorter and less repetitive, the already promised Quarian Ark DLC and a flying vehicle to make navigating the maps less tedious. Even just making all fast travel locations unlocked from the start so that you don't have to spend hours Death Stranding across the maps would make the game much better.

snippet.textDisplay:
one of my favorite improvements so far, is the stuff provided by the winter event which is: u can spend the seasonal currency and get legendary/masterwork armor, and more cosmetics. Its really easy to get the currency. There are no new strongholds. and no new areas to explore really.
I'm also really sad that i didn't play during Halloween to get the mass effect themed armor for the javelins.

snippet.textDisplay: They improved the loot system to the point were you can choose what type of legendary you want to get (ranger parts,other javelin part, weapons) you get them a lot more as a drop and you can use  event currency to buy packs with legendary gear only, They did put more mission in that require puzzle solving so mission became better than the 3-4 original missions you had(protect,gather,kill) cosmetic got better since they put a lot of items behind achievement so doing the event was worth it, but at the same time the shop is bad as it was they need to take some pages from their mmo swtor on that, and crafting got worst since there is no point on using it other than craft combat boosters, story had some development but not much and they didn't do anything to promote clans on the game so finding the right people to do achievement run of big score runs was very difficult and people only managed that through discords.

snippet.textDisplay:
Nice setup! This is my first look at the News show. I'm looking forward to seeing what the 2.0 is going to be like. As a Mass Effect fan who felt deeply betrayed by Andromeda, I looked-at the similarities between Anthem's cooperative gameplay and ME3's stunningly awesome co-op mode... and I'm about it. Anthem, as a live-service looter-shooter, I look at how many others of its kind, that still have major issues today with monetization and functional service-of-game to its fanbase, and I wonder where that line is actually drawn...

With a new Mass Effect project in the works, and EA's current track to redeem things on the long-term, Imma hang-on to this because I want to see the revisions. There's a nuanced artistry to the story, the world, the characters, and the gameplay that I really want to see fully-realized. What sucks the most about all of this is how even the track record of other looter-shooter games that got fixed still lose interest over-time. Look-at Division 1 with fans in an outcry over 2 not having anything like Underground and Survival endgame DLC. Even after the New York expansion that's recently revealed.

But the turn-around for quality game goodness, particularly for the looter-shooter genre and it's currently premiering competition for the next consoles, can be expected-to fail out the door, because we've already allowed that to happen several years ago, again and again. Breakpoint was arguably worse on-release IMO cause it didn't deserve that Division of treatment to its decades-long fanbase, and it barely functioned as a game throughout the rest of the year. Yet I'm holding onto it to see the changes come-through because there's proof-of-life I still see in the game that has great potential. I wanna see my consumer investment made back to me, while I don't buy anything else Ubi's selling until it happens. We'll see on that one.

I think that the games-as-a-service model is going to be significantly more-prominent in the next console generation, as much as current backwards-compatibility emulation is implied. The evolutionary process of changing a game to keep the fans playing can devise a developers' long-term goals for a fan-supported, fan-invested product IP. I just wish that the "beta-testing" process we all signed-up for wasn't so painful to watch. Where's the line drawn for these games to be "done" before they are "done"?

Great video!

snippet.textDisplay: You can't fix a bad game by adding to it. You need to take the bad stuff out. The entire story campaign needs to be rewritten and replaced. I think a lot of developers go through the trouble of designing a huge map, making tons of art assets and animations and then use all that work on a rushed poorly conceived game. The worst example of a huge waste of art assets in the history of the video game industry was LA Noire. The game had one of the biggest most detailed maps ever in a game and all you did in it was drive from mission to mission. That map could have easily been reused for a half dozen open world games. Bioware take your art assets and make a new game as if Anthem never existed. If you are beholden to whatever concept you had while making Anthem you will just hold yourself back from making the best game you can. Get some fresh eyes on the project keep flying and your map and go from there.

If you are beholden to whatever concept you had while making Anthem you will just hold yourself back from making the best game you can. Get some fresh eyes on the project keep flying and your map and go from there.

snippet.textDisplay:
I had to laugh at this announcement, this is the future of games people! Sell it, then eventually patch it or work on it and make promises to get better.
I can tell you what happens, it will seel more to this, maybe a few patches at best, a second version maybe, Anthme 2.0, copy pasted with minor adjustments, make more money, then "the numbers not hit our expectations", servers closed, Gaem forgotten, but hey they maked there moeny still right? CEO's getting there bonus and developers get moved ot a new project or even fired after.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: I hope that Anthem 2.0 becomes another Final Fantasy XIV story.   There were glimpses of brilliance in the game, it was one of the most natural and intuitive flight systems, and the gun play felt solid for me, good responsive gunplay, I hope the rework fixes things the right way, I want those loot pinatas when I kill a difficult enemy, I want to be rewarded for going up in difficulty.
snippet.textOriginal: I hope that Anthem 2.0 becomes another Final Fantasy XIV story.   There were glimpses of brilliance in the game, it was one of the most natural and intuitive flight systems, and the gun play felt solid for me, good responsive gunplay, I hope the rework fixes things the right way, I want those loot pinatas when I kill a difficult enemy, I want to be rewarded for going up in difficulty.
